metadata.synopsis: It's summer break and college freshman Lewis Thomas (Paul Walker) has decided to embark on a cross-country road trip to pick up the girl of his dreams, Venna (Leelee Sobieski). But Lewis' romantic hopes hit a detour when he stops on the way to rescue his older brother, Fuller (Steve Zahn), who goads him into playing a practical joke on a lonely trucker, over a CB radio. Now, that trucker, an unseen and terrifying force known only by his CB handle, Rusty Nail, wants the last laugh and revenge.

reviews: Although its premise may not be original, Joy Ride is still tense, chilling escapism.
...boasts a number of genuinely exhilarating sequences and set-pieces.
Will convince you that you'd be better off taking the train.
America's dark and lonely back roads are the prime location for stories about relentless, psychotic stalkers preying on the youth.
Nothing special -- it just devotedly does its job to give the audience a string of suspense scenarios.
Maybe it's a wonderful inside joke - a suspenseless suspense film.
The popcorn thriller manages to keep the viewer's disbelief at bay, while offering a deceptively smooth ride through some frequently bumpy territory.
It's a scary film; an atmospheric, unrelenting, character-rich thriller that includes one of the most jolting shock-moments I can remember.
Things are pushed over the top rather successfully, but breaking momentum is a pretty big mistake for movie that wants to wow us with ruthless efficiency.
It's what we don't see that terrifies us in Roadkill, a blistering good thriller that keeps us uneasy and perched on the edge of our seats.
Well done thriller just when we need it most.
A thriller driven by considerable suspense before taking a wrong exit somewhere near the end.
This is a drive-in movie supreme, a suspense saga with several wicked shocks and at least as many hearty laughs.
